text:
Tillary Street, west from Jay Street, showing more of the south side of the street.  The 6-story white building is the Brooklyn Edison Company Building, at Pearl Street, and beyond that, across the "El," is a corner of the United States Post Office.  In the left background is the Montague-Court Building.

View 1: June 2, 1931
View 2: September 9, 1939
P. L. Sperr

View 2 shows the S.E. corner of Tillary and Jay Streets, Tillary being on the left, extending to Lawrence Street; Jay Street is on the right.  The cleared area is the same as that seen on the right in view 1, where the buildings were razed.
folder: Tillary St. & Jay St., Brooklyn, NY

text:
Front Street, south side, east from Jay Street. Also shown, is Jay Street, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Front Street, as seen across Vacant lot at the S.W. corner. Occupants of same, are the National
Lead Co., and Brooklyn Edison Co. (Station 44).
March 9, 1937.
. Sperr.  RO N88PRODUCTIONS.

text:
Jay Street, west side north from a point south of Front Street, to the East River.  In order, are the buildings coupled by the Grand Union Tea Co.; the John Masury Paint Co.; and the Arbuckle Bros. Coffee Co. In the background, towering over Manhattan, is the Empire State Building.  [UNCLEAR HANDWRITING]  March 9, 1937.
P.L. Sperr

text:
Jay Street, east side, at, adjoining and north of Concord Street, showing homes being demolished, to make way for new buildings. The Independent Subway passes under ground at this point, and is a boon to property owners in the area.

December 15, 1936.

F. L. Sperr
folder: Jay Street & Concord Street, Brooklyn, NY

text:
(1) Jay Street, east side, north from Cathedral Place. On the right, in the foreground, is seen St. James Roman Catholic Church. July 5, 1930.

(2) The same, also looking east on Cathedral Place to Pearl Street. At the right is a small public park, partially seen which are in almost every neighborhood in Greater New York. December 15, 1936.

(3)The same, a close-up of buildings on the north side of the church, showing also a segment of the Sperry Building. December 15, 1936.
